DSS_METRIC_DESCRIPTIONS.METRIC_DESCRIPTION: Avoid using the call of web service jQuery ajax inside a loop

When designing web service to get/put/post data, you want to make sure that you minimize the number of calls between the client application and web service server. By minimizing the number of calls, you improve application speed, reduce communications overhead (why send three request when you can do it by one), and reduce network traffic.

When designing web service to get/post/put data, you want to make sure that you minimize the number of calls between the client application and web service server. This rule will check the official jQuery ajax syntax to do call to web service.
Try to create a process queue that will manage all the requests with a limited number of concurrents requests. When a request callback has been managed a new request could be fired.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery resource service artifacts (JQuery GET resource service, JQuery PUT resource service, JQuery POST resource service)
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using element type in jQuery
Ensure that using jQuery selector request do not lead to a performance issue.
When using class selectors, don't use the element type in your selector.
var $products = $(".products"); // FAST
var $products = $("div.products"); // SLOW
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Implement success and error or complete callbacks when using jquery web service call before jQuery 3.0

Ensure that each web service callback is going to be properly checked in order to make sure you will not miss any problem that occurred in your application and you will give the information to the user.
Before jQuery 3.0, when using $.ajax, $.get, $.getJSON interface to do web service calls, always ensure you have implemented the success and error or complete callbacks.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery resource service artifacts (JQuery GET resource service, JQuery PUT resource service, JQuery POST resource service)
Number of violation occurrences
Always use find for Id->Child nested selectors
Ensure that using jQuery selector request do not lead to a performance issue.
Use find for Id->Child nested selectors. The .find() approach is faster because the first selection is handled without going through the Sizzle selector engine.
var $productIds = $("#products div.id"); // SLOW
var $productIds = $("#products").find("div.id"); // FAST
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Always cache the returned objects in variables to be reused
Ensure that using jQuery selector will not lead to a performance issue. Requesting Id or caching the results is a good way to improve performance.
Always cache your jQuery selector, based on class, returned objects in variables for reuse.
$("#myDiv").click(function(){...}); // FAST BECAUSE ID $(".myClass").click(function(){...}); // SLOW
var $myClass = $(".myClass"); $myClass.click(function(){...}); // FAST
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Use "type=" to select elements by type
Ensure using the "type=" annotation to improve the performance.

Using [type=xxx] is far faster because it can take advantage of the DOM querySelectorAll method in modern browsers. The check will be done on the following selectors :checkbox, :file, :image, :password, :radio, :reset, :text
Use "type=" notation instead of ":".
http://learn.jquery.com/performance/optimize-selectors/ CISQ OMG
var input = $( "form input:radio" ); // Noncompliant var input = $( "form :radio" ); // Noncompliant
var input = $( "form input[type=radio]" ); // Compliant
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid use of anonymous functions to attach events
Ensure the maintainability of the code, providing explicit function name instead of using anonymous function.
Avoid use of anonymous functions to attach events. Anonymous functions are difficult to debug, maintain, test, or reuse.
Use explicit function name
http://learn.jquery.com/code-organization/beware-anonymous-functions/
$("#myLink").on("click", function(){...}); // BAD
function myLinkClickHandler(){...} $("#myLink").on("click", myLinkClickHandler); // GOOD
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using css() of many elements
Changing display attributes thanks to .css() method could generate some performance issues.
If you're changing the CSS of more than 20 elements using .css(), consider adding a style tag to the page instead for a nearly 60% increase in speed.
Use stylesheets style tag
CISQ OMG, https://learn.jquery.com/performance/use-stylesheets-for-changing-css/
$( "a.swedberg" ).css( "color", "#0769ad" );
$( "<style type=\"text/css\">a.swedberg { color: #0769ad }</style>") .appendTo( "head" );
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid Universal Selectors
Ensure that using jQuery selector request do not lead to a performance issue.
Avoid Universal Selectors because element selections that could be matched anywhere in the document can be very slow.
http://learn.jquery.com/performance/optimize-selectors/
$('div.container > *'); // SLOW or $( ":radio" ); // Implied universal selection. or $( "*:radio" ); // Implied universal selection.
$('div.container').children(); // BETTER or $( "input:radio" ); // Much better.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using jQuery deprecated methods
Using deprecated jQuery API could lead to security compliancy issues.

Be careful when using deprecated methods. The deprecation period should be used to smoothly make the transition. The rule raises an issue when any of the following methods is used: - .andSelf() - .context - .die() - .error() - jQuery.boxModel - jQuery.browser - jQuery.sub() - jQuery.support - .live() - .load() - .selector - .size() - .toggle() - .unload()
http://api.jquery.com/die/
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using jQuery $.cookie
Component-heavy development patterns can lead to development teams not even understanding which components they use in their application or API, much less keeping them up to date.
Using deprecated jQuery API could lead to security compliancy issues. $.cookie library has been deprecated and must not be used.
Use the Cookie framework instead (https://github.com/js-cookie/js-cookie)
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10-2017_A9-Using_Components_with_Known_Vulnerabilities
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using Ajax method without dataType with jQuery version older than 3.0.0

While some known vulnerabilities lead to only minor impacts, some of the largest breaches to date have relied on exploiting known vulnerabilities in components. Depending on the assets you are protecting, perhaps this risk should be at the top of the list.

jQuery versions older than 3.0.0 are vulnerable to Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attacks when a cross-domain Ajax request is performed without the dataType option, causing text/javascript responses to be executed. This rule has been listed as CVE-2015-9251 in the CVE registry.
Always provide dataType parameter.
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2015-9251

<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-2.1.4.js"></script> 
    <script src="https://code.jquery.com/ui/1.12.0/jquery-ui.js"></script> 
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://code.jquery.com/ui/1.9.1/themes/base/ 
jquery-ui.css"> 
    <script> 
        $(document).ready(function () { 
            $('#dialog').dialog({ closeText: '<script>alert("XSS")<\/script>' }); 
        }); 
    </script>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts calling Ajax function
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using dialog with closeText parameter with jQuery UI version older than 1.12

While some known vulnerabilities lead to only minor impacts, some of the largest breaches to date have relied on exploiting known vulnerabilities in components. Depending on the assets you are protecting, perhaps this risk should be at the top of the list.

jQuery UI versions older than 1.12.0 are vulnerable to Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attacks when using dialog API with closeText argument containing html content. This rule has been listed as CVE-2016-7103 in the CVE registry.
Use a newer version of jQuery UI.
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2016-7103

<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-2.1.4.js"></script> 
    <script src="https://code.jquery.com/ui/1.11.4/jquery-ui.js"></script> 
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://code.jquery.com/ui/1.9.1/themes/base/ 
jquery-ui.css"> 
    <script> 
        $(document).ready(function () { 
            $('#dialog').dialog({ closeText: '<script>alert("XSS")<\/script>' }); 
        }); 
    </script>

Always implement done, fail and/or always callbacks for $.ajax calls when using jQuery 3.0 (and latest)

Ensure that each web service callback is going to be properly checked in order to make sure you will not miss any problem that occurred in your application and you will give the information to the user.
After jQuery 3.0, when using $.ajax, $.get, $.getJSON interface to do web service calls, always ensure you have implemented the done and fail or always callbacks.
Ensure the done, fail and/or always callbacks have been implemented
http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajax/#options

var jqxhr = $.ajax( "example.php" )
// Perform other work here ...
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code

Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using html() with jQuery 1.9.0 (or older)

jQuery before 1.9.0 is vulnerable to Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attacks. The jQuery(strInput) function does not differentiate selectors from HTML in a reliable fashion. In vulnerable versions, jQuery determined whether the input was HTML by looking for the '<' character anywhere in the string, giving attackers more flexibility when attempting to construct a malicious payload. In fixed versions, jQuery only deems the input to be HTML if it explicitly starts with the '<' character, limiting exploitability only to attackers who can control the beginning of a string, which is far less common. This rule has been listed as CVE-2012-6708 in the CVE registry.
This rule will search the use of html(), with some HTML content like <...>, in code using jQuery libraries with version before 1.9.0.
Do not use .html() or upgrade the jQuery library version
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2012-6708
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of jQuery methods
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using $(location.hash) with jQuery version older than 1.6.3

While some known vulnerabilities lead to only minor impacts, some of the largest breaches to date have relied on exploiting known vulnerabilities in components. Depending on the assets you are protecting, perhaps this risk should be at the top of the list.

Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in jQuery older than version 1.6.3, when using location.hash to select elements, allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via a crafted tag. This rule has been listed as CVE-2011-4969 in the CVE registry.
Do not use jQuery $(location.hash)
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2011-4969

<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.6.2.js"></script>
... $(location.hash) // XSS vulnerability ...

<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.6.3.js"></script>
... $(location.hash) // XSS vulnerability blocked ...
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of JQuery artifacts
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using .append() after() with jQuery 1.4.2 (or older)

While some known vulnerabilities lead to only minor impacts, some of the largest breaches to date have relied on exploiting known vulnerabilities in components. Depending on the assets you are protecting, perhaps this risk should be at the top of the list. jQuery 1.4.2 allows remote attackers to conduct cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks via vectors related to use of the text method inside after. This rule has been listed as CVE-2014-6071 in the CVE registry.
This rule will search for the usage of "append" and "after" jQuery functions in code using jQuery 1.4.2 (or older) library
Do not use append(), after() or upgrade the version of jQuery
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-6071

<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.4.2.js"></script> 
  <script>
    $(function() {
      $('#users').each(function() {
        var select = $(this);
        var option = select.children('option').first();
        select.after(option.text()); // VULNERABILITY
        select.hide();
      });
    });
  </script>

<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.6.0.js"></script> 
  <script>
    $(function() {
      $('#users').each(function() {
        var select = $(this);
        var option = select.children('option').first();
        select.after(option.text()); // NO VULNERABILITY
        select.hide();
      });
    });
  </script>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of jQuery methods
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using attr() with jQuery 3.0.0-rc1

While some known vulnerabilities lead to only minor impacts, some of the largest breaches to date have relied on exploiting known vulnerabilities in components. Depending on the assets you are protecting, perhaps this risk should be at the top of the list. jQuery 3.0.0-rc1 is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) due to removing a logic that lowercased attribute names. Any attribute getter using a mixed-cased name for boolean attributes goes into an infinite recursion, exceeding the stack call limit. This rule has been listed as CVE-2012-6708 in the CVE registry.
This rule will search for calls to "attr" function with jQuery library 3.0.0-rc1.
Do not use jQuery "attr" function or update the jQuery library version
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2016-10707 https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2914

<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.0.0-rc1.js"></script> ...
console.log($('<div>').attr('requiRed'));
...

<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.0.1.js"></script> ...
console.log($('<div>').attr('requiRed'));
...
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code

Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using Dialog Widget with jQuery UI version older than 1.10.0

While some known vulnerabilities lead to only minor impacts, some of the largest breaches to date have relied on exploiting known vulnerabilities in components. Depending on the assets you are protecting, perhaps this risk should be at the top of the list. Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in jquery.ui.dialog.js in the Dialog widget in jQuery UI before 1.10.0 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via the title option. This rule has been listed as CVE-2010-5312 in the CVE registry.
This rule will search for the usage of "dialog" function in jQuery code using jQuery UI version older than 1.10.0
Do not use .dialog() or update the version of jQuery
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2010-5312
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code

Avoid using Tooltip widget with jQuery UI version older than 1.10.0

Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the default content option in jquery.ui.tooltip.js in the Tooltip widget in jQuery UI before 1.10.0 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via the title attribute, which is not properly handled in the autocomplete combo box demo. While some known vulnerabilities lead to only minor impacts, some of the largest breaches to date have relied on exploiting known vulnerabilities in components. Depending on the assets you are protecting, perhaps this risk should be at the top of the list. This rule has been listed as CVE-2012-6662 in the CVE registry.
This will search for the usage of jQuery function "tooltip" where title attribute is changed using the jQuery UI library version older than 1.10.0
Do not use jQuery tooltip or update the jQuery UI library
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2012-6662

// version of the jquery ui library is vulnerable <script src="https://code.jquery.com/ui/1.9.1/jquery-ui.js"></script> ... $( element ) .attr( "title", '<script type="text/javascript">alert("XSS");</script>') .tooltip( "open" ); ..

// version of the jquery ui library is NOT vulnerable <script src="https://code.jquery.com/ui/1.10.0/jquery-ui.js"></script> ... $( element ) .attr( "title", '<script type="text/javascript">alert("XSS");</script>') .tooltip( "open" ); ..
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
